definitions.definition: To speak or behave so as to give a false or simulated appearance.
examples: You don't have to pretend that the soup tastes fine.
You don't have to pretend to like the soup.
If you don't like it, say so. You don't have to pretend .
To get into the club, he pretended to be over 18.
She moved her fingers across the desk, pretending to play the piano.
She didn't have a real piano to play, so she just pretended .

subdefinitions.definition: To feign , affect (a state, quality, etc.).
examples: She's pretending illness to get out of the business meeting.

labels: intransitive or with 'that' clause or 'to' infinitive
definitions.label_groups: intransitive or with 'that' clause or 'to' infinitive

definitions.definition: To lay claim (to an ability, status, advantage, etc.).
examples: The family's exile was intended to stop them pretending to the throne.

definitions.definition: To hold before, or put forward , as a cloak or disguise for something else; to exhibit as a veil for something hidden .
To intend ; to design , to plot ; to attempt .
To hold before one; to extend .

main_definition: ( intransitive or with 'that' clause or 'to' infinitive ) To speak or behave so as to give a false or simulated appearance. [from 14th c.]
secondary_definitions: ( intransitive with 'to' , formal , originally transitive ) To lay claim (to an ability, status, advantage, etc.). [from 15th c.]
( transitive , obsolete ) To hold before, or put forward , as a cloak or disguise for something else; to exhibit as a veil for something hidden .
( transitive , obsolete ) To intend ; to design , to plot ; to attempt .
( transitive , obsolete ) To hold before one; to extend .
